context: The Fall. Act 3. Back in the car. Everything gone. Rain on the windshield. Devastating.

lines.text: The backseat of the CRX. The same backseat. The same cold. The same steering wheel imprint you thought you'd never feel again.
The penthouse keys are on the dash. They don't open anything anymore. The locks were changed this morning.
Your phone has seventeen missed calls. Twelve are lawyers. Three are journalists. Two are numbers you don't recognize.
You try the heater. It doesn't work. Of course it doesn't. It never worked.
Through the rain-streaked glass, you can see the skyline. Your penthouse — someone else's penthouse now — is a lit rectangle sixty stories up. A life you can see but can't touch.
The city doesn't care. It hums the same hum it hummed when you had nothing. When you had everything. When you had nothing again.
You pull the blanket from behind the passenger seat. The same blanket. It still smells like motor oil.
You close your eyes. The rain sounds the same as it did on your first night. Full circle.
Something is different though. Last time, you had nothing to lose.
This time you know exactly what you lost.
The CRX idles. The rain falls. The city hums. And somewhere inside the wreckage, something refuses to go out.
